150488049.review:
[b]Unexpectedly for an action side scroller, "Katana ZERO" shines more for its world and story that its gameplay. Its pixel graphics are gorgeous, its atmosphere has retro, melancholic vibes, its story is emotional and disturbing, its characters are adorable, its dialogues are well written and sometimes poetic. Battles are fast, kills are rewarding and although overall its action is cool, it fails to stand out. Gameplay is shallow and never really evolves. Attacking is performed by only two moves, platforming sessions are too simplistic and boss battles are unimaginative. Nevertheless, it's storytelling and atmosphere offer a nice experience.


Manometer: 8/10[/b]


The good
- Beautiful aesthetics. Gorgeous, immersive world with amazing colors and a lot of nice details.
- It has a unique, dark, retro atmosphere with its neon lights and all these tape, rewind and glitch effects. It has vibes from old arcade games and VHR players.
- Great story. Despite the initial cheerful impression the plot is pretty dark and  sometimes cruel with disturbing moments but also a few emotional, esoteric scenes of self reflection. Storytelling is even better as it tangles nicely flashbacks with dreams or nightmares and reality with illusions.
- Gameplay is simplistic and doesn't evolve much, but the levels are nicely designed to constantly add some new ideas that maintain the interest. Battles are fast and entertaining. Kills and slow motion are pleasant.
- Simple, yet effective and precise control mechanics.
- Awesome, fluid animations with great transitions.
- Well written dialogues that get pretty cryptic and poetic at some points. The feature that you can interrupt your intercalator is clever. All these colors, different styles and animations of the text replace some of the personality and emotion that was lost with the absence of voice acting.
- Adorable characters both visually and as personalities. Some of them are pretty interesting.
- Amazing electronical music that enhances the atmosphere and battle's rhythm. It fits nicely to the retro, melancholic vibes.
-  It offers enjoyable replays that are feel very rewarding after a difficult level with many enemies.
- After finishing the game speedrun and hard mode get unlock for more challenges.

The bad
- Although some new elements are introduced gradually inside the levels, its core gameplay is pretty shallow. You attack only with a slash or by throwing objects. There are no combos or complex moves, while deflect could have been more important. You don't acquire new abilities or weapons and the gameplay barely evolves.
- Platforming sequences are too simplistic. For a sidescroller with battles and a ninja I would expect climbing, jumping and walking on vertical walls to be more important.
- Boss battles are mediocre and not so imaginative.
- It overuses music, that plays almost all the time at the background in order to cover the empty of sounds environment. It's like a long video clip.

You play as a war veteran doing classified contracts for the government while using inhuman powers that allow you to slow your perception of time to cut through your enemies while dodge-rolling and parrying bullets in a fast pased fashion.

Story-wise, the game has a cleverly crafted narrative that builds up while gradually giving you clues of the protagonist’s past for you to understand what is actually going on, with occasional, short moments of comedic relief. Moreover, all of that is heavily spiced up by its fantastic music, composed by Bill Kiley and LudoWic.

To sum it up, great gameplay, clever narrative, banger OST, and zero bugs. Oh, and there’s a free DLC in the making.

This is a master class game that features extremely tight and responsive controls, mechanics and enemies that come together to give way to wonderful story that I enjoyed throughout the entire game. All of this backed up by beautifully violent visuals and an OST that really just clicks with every scene. 

Katana ZERO also has some decent playtime, and is rather enjoyable to come back to and replay again. If you really sprinted through the game, skipping almost all dialogue, you could probably beat this game in about 6 hours. However this game is best played through twice, and I'll give you a small hint, it involves your "handler".

9/10. Only thing I could have asked for is maybe some different modes, however Katana ZERO is planned to feature DLC sometime in the near future, if not already released by the time you are reading this. This game is more than worth your time.

148668531.review:
Quite possibly one of the most uncanny, and hauntingly beautiful cyberpunk action games I've ever played. It's a retro side scroll hack n slash bullet hell / time reset game. Its genres are time travel, sci-fi, psychological thriller, horror, and it's a G** D*** F***ING MASTERPIECE! I had a feeling this game was going to be amazing the moment I saw the trailer, and it still went beyond my expectations in every way. Everything from gloomily depressing, but lovably sleazy old timey hard boiled noir detective movie setting. To the piano music, to the most electronic that electronica has to offer in terms of the most retro futuristic music style a cyber punk dystopia can bounce into your eardrums. The music is one part of what makes this game PHENOMINAL.

Another thing is that takes you through a heart-warming, and gut wrenching roller coaster that has you questioning the main characters sanity, the continuity of the timeline, the nature of reality itself, followed up by the most emotionally upsetting and real world fucked up bleaker-than-bleak cliff hanger ending I've ever had the displeasure of reaching in a video game. 

No. I'm serious. I don't have another one off the top of my head that comes close for me. It's probably not most people's, but my background probably makes this game hit some nerves for me. . . I am chewing my fingernails for more hoping I we can all do something if we're careful, quick, and clever... Thing is. . . no matter what happens, the game is a emotionally razor sharp dagger to the heart in a masterful way. Most people aren't looking for that in a video game. Most people don't care what a masterful stroke of writing it takes for that to be possible. The game isn't bad because the ending isn't happy, satisfying, or ends on a cliffhanger. 

Also, if in the sequel she's dead or worse . . . & trust me I hope not, or I hope there's at least ways to avert those endings if so... but this is the devs game/work of art. Not our power fantasy. Kids all around the world every day  get violated, and snuffed. I was almost one of the ones that didn't make it. We live in a cynically bleak, and nightmarish world. Always have, and this game doesn't shy away from that. I find that to be oddly comforting. As a trafficking survivor, a recovered hard drug addict, as a veteran with ptsd, and an orphan this game had me in tears. . . It's not for the faint of heart, and the point will be missed by most edge lords too. Kid characters are not safe from harm in this story. Just a fair warning without spoilers. If that's not for you, I understand. Katana 0 was everything I never knew I needed in a very small, and precisely perfected work of art. Worth every penny, even full price, because this game is priceless.

148242899.review:
[i] Katana ZERO [/i] is an intense real-time fighting game where you, a contract killer, travel through facilities taking out goons and toppling a secret government conspiracy. The meat of the game is the backstory of our unnamed protagonist, and his ability to perceive time at a slower rate (allowing for split-second decisions like reflecting bullets).
WOW WHAT A GAME! The story is phenomenal, the dialogue portions of the game are almost as fun as the combat itself. It is SO satisfying to cut-off a villain mid-monologue, and it's REALLY COOL to get to watch a replay of your battle at regular speed. It really shows how much of an animal the protagonist is.
The story shouldn't take you longer than 4 hours, and is a wonderful adventure to play through. There are a lot of things to explore once the story is over too, and I appreciate the inclusion of a Speedrun Mode. Obviously, the art is amazing, and the music does an incredible job of setting the futuristic-techno city of New Mecca. If you like platformers and think reflecting bullets is cool as hell, you NEED this game in your library!

148222883.review:
When I first booted this game up in 2019 I expected a possibly interesting indie sleeper hit with a cool logo. I didn't know I just stumbled onto one of my all-time favorite videogames.
No-nonsense, tight and butter-smooth, charming and beautiful, well-paced and intuitive, it gets installed onto every PC I use.
The combat is so clean, tight and well-crafted it's ridiculous. Every death is either a miscalculation or a misplay, and it's satisfying to get better at it.

147930885.review:
I consider this to be the perfect game. Everything in this game is refined to a tea, including its game play, story, mechanics, humour, music, characters, art style and animations. 

Many challenges take careful coordination to complete, and leave no room for error. This game is frustrating, but it is not annoying. Every success feels satisfying and leaves you wanting more.

The story has very emotional moments, and some abstract moments that the player must interpret. It does not throw a bone to the player to make them feel good about what they are doing, it plays out realistically to how the story should progress. The music is well suited for each scene, and amplifies the emotional moments.

I cannot stress this enough, [b] this game must be experienced with audio, and optimally headphones. [/b]

The game is short (6-8 hours I would say), so make sure to space out play sessions with that in mind. Although, there is also a hard-mode which will take you much longer to complete.

I have played many popular games on steam including the portal series, half-life series, hollow knight, celeste, terraria, etc. So I do not say it lightly when I say: [/b] this is the best game I have ever played. [/b]

147879330.review:
Katana ZERO coge lo mejor de Hotline Miami y lo matiza para hacer un videojuego mucho más vistoso, entretenido e interesante. Mientras que en el otro la historia era confusa y una completa paranoia visual y auditiva que culminaba en una orgía de sangre, aquí poco a poco se va incorporando un guion adulto, triste y con toques de humor negro. 

No innova en nada, precisamente; de hecho, todas las cosas que lo hacen tan bueno recogen una fuerte inspiración de otros videojuegos, películas o libros. Lo que más destaca sin duda es su banda sonora, diseño de niveles y los personajes (que son carismáticos, misteriosos y brillantes a partes iguales). Pese a todo lo que ha cogido prestado de otros medios, eso no quita que sea posiblemente el que mejor lleva a cabo todo.

I'm going through my library and playing games to 100% to revive my love for gaming rather than mindlessly playing video games.

This game stands separate from many due to the mechanics and the smoothness of gameplay. It can be quite difficult to grasp the game however when you finally find that strategy to beat a level there is a huge satisfaction. This game also showed me how difficult speedrunning truly is due to one of the achievements. I had a very hard time with the speedrun but once I nailed the gold medal I felt amazing. The secrets that were in the game were fun and entertaining rather than just simply a single easter egg with an achievement. I know there was supposed to be a DLC released and we still have not heard anything else but I wish I could have had more time to learn about some characters that seemed they were going to be more relevant.

147115719.review:
I cannot overstate how fucking hard it is to write a review of Katana Zero. Which raises the question: how the fuck did the developers write Katana Zero????

Is this the work of a genius or of a madman, we will never know. What I do know is that I did not expect this neon hack-n-slash game to shine through it’s story of all things, but my god does it shine.
It’s funny, it’s clever, it’s surreal and deals with fucking time distortion -excuse the cursing, even writing this review has me going slightly mad. I should be studying law right now. I cannot, for this game won’t leave my brain alone. This is catharsis.

The gameplay is also mind-bogglingly good. The levels are surprisingly varied, they sit juuuust at the right difficulty level for me, and succeeding at them never failed to make me (mid gamer) feel like an absolute badass (and a monster. I don’t care about killing people in video games, they’re video games right - but Zero cared, and so I cared.) Everything about its aesthetics serves the story and gameplay, from each lair you have to infiltrate from the city, your apartment, and especially the excellent soundtrack and the whole…surveillance camera system.

Free will is a lie, my life is a lie, aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaah

146516039.review:
This isn't a bad game and it has a lot of things I enjoyed but if I had to pick yes/no for it, ultimately I come down as a "no".

The biggest one is just that the story is very unfinished. Where you end is basically the end of the prelude with the "real story" just about to start. There are tons of dangling plot threads. This isn't a "everything got wrapped up" kind of Part 1. This is more like Half-Life 2: Episode 2. And it's been 4 years with nothing else.

It's a problem because what sets this above many of the other Hotline Miami inspired games is the story. But ultimate it ends up going nowhere with no resolution because the game just ends.

The other reason I lean towards "no" is the gameplay has just enough things that are unsatisfying. You see all there is to offer in terms of gameplay reasonably early in the game. You've seen all the enemy types and the general kind of level designs. The gameplay leans a little bit more in the Dragon's Lair "memorise the events and twitch respond" direction than I prefer. There are a lot of corridors here and often only 1 or 2 ways to get through them. The way it handles death along with the pixel art occasionally makes it hard to tell exactly what you did wrong. I would have liked to see the option for a slow motion replay. How exactly did I pull those enemies from the second floor that time? A lot of the later levels increase the difficulty by just making the level longer, so a mistake on the 26th enemy means death and resetting to the beginning. I would have preferred if difficulty increased in some other way, since it often got tedious to redo the first 2/3rd of a level 20+ times.

Don't get me wrong, I mostly enjoyed the game. I think if the story had a better ending...or any kind of ending at all, really, it would tip me towards a "yes" despite the shortcomings in the gameplay.

146433451.review:
I thought the game was kinda meh, with a few bright spots. It's still good enough for me to recommend though.

Katana Zero is a side-scroller, where you need to kill every enemy in a room, before you can continue. Getting hit once means you're dead and need to start from the beginning. So far so good, but the game has a bit too much randomness with enemy placement and their movement for my tastes, so finding that perfect route through a level can be a pain sometimes.

Since you'll probably die a bunch, I believe a game like this needs a really snappy restart of a level / room, like Super Meat Boy, but it takes just a bit too long in my opinion.

The story could have been interesting, but I just didn't like the way it's told. What is good though, is the dialog system. When your character can say something, you get a timed response you can select. You can either interrupt the other speaker or wait for them to finish and choose from a few options. Depending on your choices, this can really add to the game.

The game does look great, and the music is very good as well.

Katana Zero is pretty short, and you're supposed to play through the game at least twice, I guess. I'll pass on that, just finishing it once is enough for me.

145071368.review:
[h1] Katana Zero Review: A Time-Bending Tale of Redemption [/h1]

Hey there, it's Kenstagator, diving into the intriguing world of Katana Zero. 

Let's talk samurai assassins, time manipulation, and a dash of gory redemption.

Imagine a game that doesn't just embrace your failures, but practically celebrates them. That's Katana Zero in a nutshell. Developed by Askiisoft, this 2D side-scrolling action adventure thrusts you into the shoes of Zero, an amnesiac samurai with a deadly task and a unique ability to manipulate time thanks to a mind-bending drug.

As Zero, you gracefully dodge, slice, and deflect through stages, feeling like a true sword-wielding badass. Bullet time becomes your trusty companion, allowing you to orchestrate cinematic carnage with style. While the gameplay is solid, it does have its limitations. The combat, while polished, can feel a bit restrained due to a limited variety of enemies and environments.

But here's where it gets interesting. The game's repetitive nature isn't a flaw, it's a feature. You'll replay encounters multiple times to perfect your moves, fitting right into the theme of mastery through defeat. There's something oddly satisfying about nailing that scenario after a dozen attempts, but it can also start to feel a bit predictable.

The story adds layers to this repetition. Zero is no typical hero; he's a loner with a tragic reliance on Chronos, the time-altering drug. It's a double-edged sword – it grants power but exacts a heavy price. The story deftly explores the choices he faces: endless violence or a plunge into oblivion.

Interactive moments and dialogue choices give you some control over Zero's journey. These segments, while not drastically affecting the main plot, deepen your connection with him and his struggles. The narrative unfolds against a backdrop of dark, meticulously animated scenes that blend seamlessly with the gameplay.

The game's atmosphere oozes neon-lit grit, with pulsating music enhancing both action-packed sequences and story-driven dialogues. Sure, Katana Zero can be a bit grim at times, and the gameplay variety isn't groundbreaking, but it still manages to captivate. The game's unique style and sincere storytelling make it stand out even in its cynical and sometimes ugly world.

So, if you're up for a dose of samurai action with a twist of time manipulation and a side of introspection, Katana Zero could be your next gaming adventure!

145068562.review:
A beautiful symphony or blood and what's no longer... or what was never there. If the trailer didn't do a good enough job of presenting the visuals, combat, and absolutely wall-bangin' music: Get the game. If you're even slightly interested, get it. If you liked the music and listened to LudoWic's stuff on youtube or another service, get the game. Katana zero is loved, and it will not disappoint.

You start the game thrown into the levels of blood you must paint - the only thing the game really needs to tell you is to kill. And you will. But look past that, look past the surface dialogue and the red-painted walls and there's a masterpiece of a story to be told. Did I forgot to mention, you can slow down time? Levels aren't just something to run-through like a madman - later ones are a puzzle you will retry over and over again. As if you're actually experienced in the art of what the game needs you to do, you must remain calm and ordered.

I'm not here to spoil the story. Combat is snappy and satisfying [if you like the blood]. The story is beautiful and runs right up next to it's music. I can't tell you how many times I've listened to the soundtrack outside of the game. There's also a ~secret~ boss, but it's easier to simply play through the (always free) dragon DLC of the game to experience it.

Go have fun, and think about [i]why[/i] you're killing sometimes. The game ends, but only in the way you'd expect if you understood the story.

144452730.review: If you found the trailer compelling: Yes, the game actually feels like all of that in practice. The story is, regrettably, at time of writing still egregiously unfinished, leaving it one of those games that just "stops" instead of "finishes", but the ride to that stop is absolutely worth it. Katana Zero offers tight controls, simple but adequately challenging gameplay, and high difficulty made fun by a lightning-fast gameplay loop. The mechanic of each playthrough being essentially a plan or rehearsal of what your supersoldier protagonist is going to do, with the "real" action playing out afterwards without any of the time-slowing effects he subjectively experiences, is brilliant, letting you see how his inhuman reflexes would look to those without them. And that's only one of the many ways the game exploits its premise for creative effect. Just a great time all around.

I swear, it must be a fundamental law of the universe that every violent action indie game has the most bangin' soundtrack you've ever heard in your life. Hotline Miami (1+2), ULTRAKILL, Furi, and now Katana Zero. I went into the game expecting a fun little game where you slash some baddies. I did not expect to have an eargasmic experience. My favorite tracks in the game have to be Overdose, Nocturne, and Blue Room (11 minute verson). Sneaky Driver and Third District are also fantastic.

And the writing is... surprisingly good! This game has a really compelling story and some genuinely impactful dialogue (and a great sense of humor). I was also surprised at the technical depth of the dialogue system, with variations on how dialogue is presented and often allowing the player to interrupt NPCs for unique interactions.

My only problem with the game is that it is too short (2-3 hours total). However, a second chapter is planned to come out... soon, I think? You can also go for achievements if you want to extend your time with the game but be warned -- they can be quite difficult (I still haven't gotten the speedrun achievement).

The game is just so good. It's smooth, well-made, the levels are fun, and the story is absolutely phenomenal. The music is just too good. The graphics are great. The humour is great. The combat is perfect. I can't overstate the quality.
That being said, the best parts of the game come in when you start speedrunning the game. I know that sounds like it's not everyone's cup of tea, but it's really really easy to get the game time down by using the Speedrun mode and practising. It's just so smooth and even though it's a one-hit kill, you feel unstoppable. It's very comparable to Hotline Miami, but with more heavy and movement-heavy gameplay (and it is very very clearly inspired by Hotline Miami). 
The extra features of the game, being the Hard Mode and the challenge sections, are just so immaculately done. They do exactly as advertised and are just so good at it. I won't lie, I didn't get into the game immediately, but once you get the mechanics down, it's unbeatable. It just screams "cool", and is.

Don't be fooled by my playtime. I've had the Switch version longer and bought this one recently because I really hate playing(any game) on Switch and for no other reason.... I have 30 hours of playtime with it(this is a very short game, you can complete it in like 4 hours if you don't know what you're doing...like 2 if you do know what you're doing. I have by now completed this game more times than I have completed almost any game). 

Narratively this is the best game I've ever played. I'm not being hyperbolic as far as writing is concerned this is as good as any game has ever been imho. The gameplay is good too, combat is more like a puzzle, you're a psychic and when you "die" you just say "that won't work" and go back in time to plan out your attack again. Everything is one touch deaths with the exception of bosses but they usually go down in few hits while still killing you in one hit. The way this game blends story with gameplay is in such a way that this is a really great story that also would only really benefit from being written for a video game. Also you can flirt with a weeby hotel employee who thinks you're hot because you have a katana, which as we all know makes this game a masterpiece objectively.

The only downside is waiting 2 million years for the DLC but I do want shorter games with worse graphics and for them to take longer to develop so people aren't literally crunch culture-ing themselves to death just to make games so...I support Justin in his long process of continuing this story very very slowly and am mostly just happy that a game this good even gets to exist in the first place.

142222132.review:
[h1][b]Slashing Through the Shadows…[/b][/h1]
» [b]Katana Zero[/b] is a blisteringly fast indie slash-em-up with action that is an absolute adrenaline rush. Taking more than a few cues from [b]Hotline Miami[/b], it is largely about a drug-addicted neo-noir-inspired samurai who sticks a bunch of needles in his body. It wears its inspirations on the sleeves of its kimono but refines the tried and true one-hit-kill formula in a manner that makes it feels fresh, exciting, and innovative in surprising ways.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
» This game puts you in control of a nameless samurai assassin with the power to manipulate time and see into the future. In an extremely clever and fun framing of the action, every level is contextualized as being the planning of an assassination. So, instead of your character dying, you are told “No… That won’t work,” as your precognition rewinds to the start (complete with old-timey VCR effect), giving you a chance to find a solution that does not end in your death. Every level ends with a security camera recording of what “actually” happened, which serves not only as a way to see your moment of triumph played back but also to subvert expectations in interesting ways later on.

Working up to that moment is a blast because Katana Zero’s action is fast-paced and empoweringly flexible. Like Hotline Miami, it is one shot, one kill for both you and any enemy that is not a boss. Your character can slash in eight directions, slow down time, use a dodge roll to avoid bullets or reflect bullets back with his sword. There is a great flow and feel to your character’s movement thanks to small touches like how each sword swing gives you a slight boost of momentum, or how you can cancel out of any roll, and the way each kill gives a satisfying screen-shake and pause to the action.

However, the most iconic feature of this platformer is the slow-mo effect – specifically, how optional it is. It never feels too strong; it is on a pretty strict cooldown, and since enemies will hear whenever gunfire rings out, you will rarely have time to stay safe long enough for it to replenish. This puts it in a perfect spot as a powerful ability to get you through a tough situation while still being limited enough to keep the action quick.

[h1]Story[/h1]
» The story of Katana Zero does not quite hit the high note that its action does, but it is at least carried by strong writing and a few great characters, such as your boss/therapist that guides you through your traumatic past while also providing you with the dossiers of people he wants dead, as well as a psychotic Russian adversary named V. It unfolds in a dystopian neo-noir setting, where you are entangled in a web of conspiracies and government experiments. Exploring deep themes of trauma, identity, and the consequences of one's actions, Katana Zero poses itself as a dark and mature tale, artfully woven into the fabric of the gameplay experience.

For instance, there is an innovative dialogue system that allows players to choose unique options based on their timing and interjections. By rudely shutting down conversations or patiently listening, players can unlock different dialogue paths, adding entertaining depth to the game. However, while these choices provide multiple playthrough opportunities, the story deviations feel superficial, and later dialogue options can be inconsistent with previous decisions. Additionally, the game’s narrative leaves much unresolved, hinting at a potential sequel or DLC, but the lack of payoff in this first chapter may leave players feeling unsatisfied.

While Katana Zero will not take more than four to six hours to complete, it is a very tight four to six hours that cuts out any fluff. It never feels like it is running out of ideas, and every level does a great job of introducing small twists to its simple formula, from an underground minecart level to a motorcycle chase sequence on the city highway.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
» It also helps that everything looks and sounds great. The slick neon aesthetic and fantastic sprite work go hand in hand with some legitimately impressive 2D lighting effects that give this game a unique visual style and personality. Accompanied by a fitting and catchy retro-electro soundtrack, the audio elements perfectly complement the intense action.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
» All in all, Katana Zero’s time-bending samurai action is the star of the show here, but it's unique presentation and entertaining dialogue go a long way in supporting a plot that suffers from feeling like it is saving its best ideas for a sequel. As action games go, the game’s shorter length makes it a quick fix, and I’ll no doubt suffer withdrawal while I wait for the next hit.

[h1][b]Score: 8.7/10[/b][/h1]

Rating: ★★★★☆

The game's story and storytelling pleasantly surprised me, keeping me engrossed throughout, eager to see what the next mission held. It was the kind of game I finished in one sitting, later reflecting on the details I may have missed. The ability to shape the main character's path and personality was a standout aspect of the narrative.

The game mechanics and art design are commendable. Despite some portions being repetitive, it exceeded my expectations overall. I appreciated the challenging scenarios reminiscent of souls games, particularly the boss fights. However, I found the motocycle episode unnecessarily prolonged and somewhat out of place in the overall game experience.

The music, narrative, atmosphere, and storytelling are noteworthy. Given its price point, I would recommend this 4-star game to anyone.

142180503.review:
TLDR: Lightning fast 2d slasher, cyberpunk themes, and a very high difficulty curve. It's worth the money.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Fast paced, and very flashy. You kill instantly, but can die instantly too, and in the hard mode speedrun, you're gonna die 500-1000 times at minimum. Thankfully it's portioned out appropriately so there's no worry of having to redo long sections.

[b]Achievements[/b]
All achievements are fairly easily doable, although the method to get the keys was quite obscure and I needed a guide for that since there was no in-game indication any of these keys even existed. The 2 most notable achievements were the gold medal and the hard mode achievements. The gold medal was doable, but took quite a bit of practice and using guides on youtube to improve my time. The absolute hardest, obviously, was the hardmode achievement. Getting through this can take literal hours and requires insane amounts of skill to get through, especially towards the end. It's definitely a challenge, if you're up for it.

[b]Story[/b]
Very intriguing story, it seems well integrated into the gameplay itself and peaks your interest by deliberately leaving many things unsaid. I do hope that more will come of this series, as I actually quite enjoyed the story as well as gameplay.

[b]Hate[/b]
A small criticism might be the lack of spammability with the katana, however you just need to learn the game and get better. A nice addition would be to make each bullet parry not cooldown your slash, something I found to be an annoyance especially in hard mode. The devs did a good job, but they also need to produce much more content to fully sate the players hunger.

142161199.review:
Never have I been more genuinely and instantly intrigued as I was when I first played this game. The trailer hyped this up perfectly, and the game delivered everything I was hoping for and much more. Very underappreciated for how amazing the story and gameplay is. While the combat is mediocre the game makes every level feel intense and heart-racing. Planning out how to complete a level based on enemy AI, your own abilities, etc. makes you feel intelligent and makes the gameplay phenomenal. That layer of having to think makes Katana Zero almost feel like a puzzle game. The quick decisions matched with the rougelike resetting once you die allows you to make educated decisions and try different approaches. When you die (Which I personally did a lot) you gain further knowledge and so can try again. Dying doesn't feel like as much of a loss as it does a new step in completing the level. Combine this with the difficulty of the game and a challenging but fun and genuinely amazing new experience is born. It's art style and animation flow perfectly with the gameplay, making everything feel real and stressful. Katana Zero's gameplay, while amazing, is only half of what makes this game worth buying however. Without spoiling the story, all I can say is that you will be instantly captivated and motivated to find out everything. What's great is: YOU can. The dialogue options genuinely feel realistic and allow us to put ourselves into the shoes of the MC flawlessly. Dialogue from NPC's and how they react/how the story progresses is entirely up to you. If you want to rush through everything, go ahead, but there will be ingame consequences. I was able to step into the shoes of our MC and genuinely connect with the story. Choosing dialogue options felt good and felt like a real part of the game. One of my personal favorite parts takes place when our main character is tied up to a chair without his sword (Trying to avoid spoilers so I won't say anything else.) The dialogue options in this section feel perfect. You know exactly the type of situation you're in, and that's reflected on your character. It is a perfect section. Throughout it, a smile grew on my face, that of smugness because I felt what the MC was feeling, it was like being totally in sync.
Overall, it was phenomenal. would recommend to literally everybody, and I'm 100% sure that the only people who wouldn't enjoy it are people who hate living.

141959037.review:
I've been sleeping on pixel art games, side scrollers, platformers, and the like. Yeah, that's not gonna be the case anymore. This game is a masterpiece. I got it on sale, but it is well worth the full price. If you have a Steam Deck, this game is perfect on it, otherwise use a controller.

I didn't encounter any bugs. Combat, once you get the hang of it, can move at such a break-neck pace that levels can be completed in mere moments. The game play is very rewarding. There were quite a few times that made me think, "This is the feeling I've been chasing in video games."

The story, while short and surprisingly lacking in details, was so well crafted that I got it on the first go around. Each character has little character development, but the style and speed of the game only required that they be memorable, which they all are.

If you are going to buy only one game of this type, this should be it. I will be putting in the hours to 100% the achievements. Just get it. Stop reading reviews and go download it now.

141900960.review:
This game is short, cheap, and actually amazing. Usually I evaluate games based on visuals, music, story, and gameplay. This game has a really unique and outstanding art style, incredible music, a mysterious and engaging story, as well as some of the most fun mechanics and gameplay I've gotten to play.

This game however has one thing that a lot of games don't have. The game and what you experience while playing the game is tied to the story. Shit gets weird in this game and you will quickly realize that no, the game isn't glitching, this is as intended. It leads to some really fun and weird story and gameplay moments that will catch you off guard even after the first time you experience it.

Most of all the game is short and doesn't overstay it's welcome, but allows for replayability through achievements, speedrunning, and alternate swords that change the gameplay just a little. Also I believe you can mod the game but I can't speak on that since I played unmodded.

Overall the game easily hits a 10/10 for me, I really feel like anyone could appreciate this game, especially people who enjoy those high octane games like hotline miami.

Long Review:

Great game, although throughout the whole game i kept comparing it to hotline miami because it heavely took its inspiration there. It is the same kind of game even though it's not the same camera and the gameplay widely differs because your character uses katana and throwable items you can find on the through the level and you can slow time and it is heavely linked to the plot (Nicely done not much game try to do that anymore). 

The story unlike hotline miami 1 doesn't propose a real end but an opening for the next game in the franchise, i'm fine with it but it bugs me a little bit. I wish you could avoid killing "innocent" cops, there's just people doing their job but to proceed to next levels you have to kill everyone.

This game is done rather quickly it took me 4 and a half hour, and after finishing it i wanted to do another run to unlock everything like these kind of games usually do, they compensate small time play with replayability but the last levels of the game are really really hard, not as hard as i would get stuck on it for 3 hours but the kind of hard that gets tiring real quick and because of those level which are a bit dumbed down to die and try.

I am not a big fan of this as i prefer some level that require problem solving or finding a boss weakness but jesus the last boss and the one controlling the room or the bike level is what's keeping me from doing it again.

Even though i'm not a fan of the end game i still really liked the dialogues, at the beginning of the game i pissed off the guy on the phone to see what would happen and the result was funny. The option to talk is a huge plus compared to hotline miami and gives another reason to understand fully the whole picture as the game is very vague at the beginning but just like a movie with a plotwist during a new game you can pick up foreshadowing and understand why something specific happened etc. 

Toward the end i still was trying to block with mouse2 like an idiot because of other game reflexes haha, and by the end i still got fair bit of misinput and this is why this game absolutely need a sequel.

The Music is great, it's what got me to play this game i knew after listening to Tunç Çakır - Blue Room (feat. LudoWic) i knew i had to play this game.

The Artistic Direction is well done it's pixel art but the colours are not picked blindly there's thinking behind it, the picture is pleasing

P.S: I already said that the game includes the game mechanics in dialogues and in the story but it also clearly include the fact that you are dying and coming back to restart a level, with your enemies saying remarks about it or giving new dialog! And this is pretty brilliant

Katana Zero is an absolute gem of a game that delivers a thrilling and captivating experience from start to finish. This indie action title combines tight gameplay, a gripping narrative, and stylish aesthetics to create an unforgettable journey that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

One of the standout aspects of Katana Zero is its fast-paced and incredibly satisfying combat system. As the silent and deadly protagonist, armed with a razor-sharp katana, you'll slash through enemies with precision and finesse. The combat mechanics are flawlessly executed, allowing for fluid movement, time-manipulation abilities, and strategic planning. Each encounter feels like a meticulously choreographed dance of death, rewarding skill and quick reflexes.

Beyond its exhilarating gameplay, Katana Zero offers a rich and intricate narrative that keeps you engrossed throughout the game. The story unfolds in a non-linear fashion, with choices and consequences that shape the outcome. As a samurai assassin plagued by hallucinations and haunted by his past, the game delves into themes of identity, morality, and the consequences of our actions. The writing is top-notch, filled with twists and turns that will leave you questioning everything.

Visually, Katana Zero is a feast for the eyes. The pixel art style is stunning, combining vibrant colors, atmospheric lighting, and detailed environments. Each level is meticulously designed, creating a cyberpunk-inspired world that oozes style and personality. The accompanying soundtrack complements the gameplay and aesthetics perfectly, immersing you in the dark and moody atmosphere.

What sets Katana Zero apart is its attention to detail and the seamless integration of its gameplay and narrative elements. The game employs a dialogue system that lets you shape conversations and outcomes, adding an extra layer of immersion and player agency. The time-manipulation mechanics also play a significant role in both combat and storytelling, creating a sense of urgency and tension.

Furthermore, the game's replayability factor is high, with multiple branching paths, hidden secrets, and alternative endings. Uncovering all the hidden truths and experiencing different storylines provides ample incentive to dive back into the game and explore every nook and cranny.

In conclusion, Katana Zero is an absolute must-play for action game enthusiasts and fans of gripping narratives. Its razor-sharp combat, intricate storytelling, and stunning visuals combine to create a truly unforgettable experience. From its intense battles to its mind-bending plot twists, this game will keep you engaged and enthralled until the very end. If you're seeking an adrenaline-pumping, narrative-driven adventure, Katana Zero is an absolute standout that will leave you craving for more.

Once again, I hate that I cannot leave a neutral/informative review.

Personally, I found the gameplay to be very challenging and fun, with tight controls and great level design.
But I feel that what made this game so strong took a backseat to the lackluster storytelling.

Throughout this ~4 hour experience, I kept hesitating to skip through dialog as I was unsure what might affect said story later on. Cutscene after cutscene of nonsensical back and forth constantly gave me more questions than answers, and [personally] these took away from the fantastic gameplay that kept me engaged.

I feel this game is far to short for the pricepoint, and ending [spoiler]with a "to be continued"[/spoiler], so abruptly as well, just confirms my suspicions that a hefty focus was placed on the story instead of more missions/boss fights/etc.

I don't personally recommend it, but if it's on sale I do believe it's worth checking out to see if the story works for you. If not, I recommend setting a timer for 1:55:00.

141613535.review:
Going from room to room, ruthlessly slashing through your foes with a razor-sharp katana as a drug-addicted samurai. While not super unique at times, the story manages to be interesting. However, the game leaves us without a conclusive ending, as we are left awaiting an update, DLC, or sequel  to get the full picture. I think the pixel art style is cool and well executed although it's not something for everyone.

The gameplay leaves me somewhat conflicted. On one hand, I like that its fast pace, having the satisfaction of swiftly dispatching enemies and deflecting their bullets like a badass. Yet, it can feel cheap when you get killed by a shot across your entire screen or even offscreen with a fraction of a second to react. Additionally, I never really liked the "slowing down time" ability, as it tends to disrupt the fluidity of combat for me. Nevertheless, with convenient checkpoints at the beginning of each room, these shortcomings are somewhat mitigated, and overall, I found the combat enjoyable.

The story is only about 4-5 hours long, with no real additional content to explore. However, trying out hard mode or attempting to do a speedrun can be fun, and frustrating.

Excellent, brutal combat. You feel like a god of combat, invincible and untouchable. If you die, no matter. You are omniscient. Bullets cause more harm to those who shoot them than to you. Dozens die without ever coming close to killing you. By the end, nothing is left but corpses hacked and burned and blown up and crushed. And you.
Once all of this is done, you return to your apartment. You are a dying man. Vulnerable. You know nothing.
Excellent game, cannot wait for more.

Edit: Just realized that my review makes this game seem a bit edgy and nihilistic. That's not true. Despite the fact you are a dying, invincible god of combat, you are still human. You can choose to be kind to people. You can say thank you to the receptionist at a hotel. You take care of a little girl. And that has a small, but fun impact. Later, you meet the receptionist again and, if you were nice to her, she's happy to see you! I like that. Despite all the pain and misery you've been put through, you can still be nice.

140424737.review:
Katana Zero is freakin' addicting, man. This dystopian action platformer mixes difficulty, and and reward extremely well, due to the almost instant retry speed when you fail. Because of that, the game never feels frustrating, barring one forced (optional) stealth sequence that fits in as smoothly as a cactus in the rectum. It feels very... Hotline Miami in that sense, where you can always just throw everything at the wall and something will eventually stick. However, there is a lot more opportunity to plan your play out in KZ than in HM. 

I do have a gripe, and that is that you can't... idk, really skip the story parts on subsequent playthroughs. There is a speedrun mode, for sure! However, there is a story specific part of the game that can only be unlocked via specific choices in the story mode. So, if you didn't get it on your first run, you can't unlock it in the speedrun mode. You have to deal with the entire story, as the secret is at the very end. That's not to say the story is bad, or not fun to explore. But it's so omnipresent when I just want to hack up some dudes and find more routes/unlockables. 

The control is crisp as hell, and movement feels really good to execute. Pressing up to jump feels really weird at first, but now it feels more natural than space bar. I tried to go back to a similar sort of game, My Friend Pedro, and found myself pressing up all the time expecting to rocket off the ground. 

I hear there was some DLC planned, and a the game has such a sequel hook on it, you could get it lodged in your lip like a sturgeon. But so far... nothing else has materialized for that, at time of writing. I had so much fun playing this, and routinely come back to it, but since the levels are preset, I don't have anything new to do in it. Game is dying for an endless mode, or a procedural floor sort of run mode. 

Here, you can watch me hack, slash, and joke my way through the base story on Overlord Arcade!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kx1e6X5CIas

139969882.review:
I'd like to start with the game's (in my opinion) most prominent feature: the story. Katana Zero has the most impressive story I've seen in a game recently. Even in your short playing time of 4-4.5 hours, the game makes you adopt its characters and make you feel happy, sad, hate and fear for them. At the same time, since we determine all the dialogues of our main character Zero, we create his character completely by ourselves. If you want, you can create an aggressive character who interrupts others before they finish speaking, or you can turn him into a good-natured and kind person. Or, as I did, I created a character who was bored with life and snapped at people at first, but when a little girl whose name I didn't even know joined the game, both me and my character changed. Of course, this diversity makes it extremely easy to put yourself in the character's shoes. On the other hand, the story presentation is very high quality and the side characters are above average. The only bad or missing part of the story for me is that it ends the game without giving the player some answers. Normally I like this storytelling as long as it's in moderation, but in Katana Zero, almost no questions are answered at the end of the game and new questions are added. This makes the ending less impressive for me.

Let's talk about the gameplay. In terms of gameplay, Katana Zero is quite similar to Hotline Miami. Katana Zero has a structure that asks you to die multiple times in each episode, learn the episodes completely with a single life, develop special tactics for each episode and play accordingly. The level designs are really impressive and the level variety is very high. There are really 10s of different chapter types. But besides that, the number of chapters that repeat each other in terms of basic logic, if not completely, is quite high. This is one of the cons of the game for me. Although the number of boss fights is quite low, the ones that are there are quite high quality. At the same time, some bosses can really annoy you with their difficulty. This makes the player feel a sense of accomplishment very well.

Finally, soundtracks of Katana Zero can be both moving and exhilarating at the same time and to summarize them in one word: Perfect.

Pros
-Excellent story and presentation
-Adopting characters
-Level design
-Section diversity
-Fast and enjoyable gameplay
-Challenging and high quality bosses, each designed differently
-Perfect soundtracks

Cons
-The story leaves many questions unanswered
-Some sections in a repetitive style
-Few bosses

I would recommend everyone to play this truly impressive game.

139771506.review:
[b]TLDR: YES. Play it. It's good.[/b]

[b]Katana Zero[/b] is a 2019 indie stealth action platformer from Askiisoft, of Tower of Heaven fame. Yeah, that old gameboy-themed indie that got really popular in 2009.

It centers around two main mechanics: [b]Time-stop[/b] and [b]precision dodging/parrying[/b].
Your moveset is basic; you run, you jump, you can slash in any direction (be it with a mouse or with an analog stick).

You have a dodge roll button that makes you briefly invulnerable to basically anything (with a few exceptions in hardmode), and can be cancelled into a slash if you need to attack immediately (although that removes your invulnerability as you're not rolling anymore).

You also have a recharging energy meter that's used to activate the [b]timestop[/b] mechanic; as long as you keep it held (or as a toggle, you can change it from the settings), the whole game slows down to a crawl, as a sorta faux-bullet-time. You generally are not REQUIRED to use it, but it synergizes perfectly with the other mechanic, the [b]parry[/b].

ALMOST any projectile in the game (that isn't lasers or similar) can be [b]parried[/b] with a well-timed slash. Depending on your inputs, it'll either go back to its sender or bounce off in whatever direction your slash was aimed, if you're aiming too far away from its shooter.
(the only catch is you can only parry one projectile per swing, so if you try to parry an entire shotgun blast you're gonna eat every other pellet except the single one you hit).

Not just that; parrying a bullet INSTANTLY removes your dodge roll cooldown, making you able to cancel that slash immediately into a roll... which can be cancelled back into ANOTHER slash, and so on. With proper timing (or with clever use of the timestop to make it more feasible) you can just ZOOM through hails of bullets, rolling through some and slashing others to give yourself another roll to go through even more of them.


At first you'll generally rely on the timestop to be able to time those things well, see when enemies shoot you and react accordingly by immediately bouncing their bullets back in their face.
But as you get used to it and master it... you can just STOP using it altogether. Every enemy type has a specific attack pattern that you can learn, and a specific timing to their reactions and firing. So the more you play, the more you'll get used to these enemies, and the snappier your runs through a room will be as you effortlessly roll and parry through everything that's thrown at you while seldom using the time stop when it's REALLY needed. It's IMMENSELY satisfying to master, if a bit obtuse to learn when you're just starting out.



Now putting that aside, Katana Zero is a pretty short game. It's a cheap indie, so yeah, it's kinda short. Took about 4 hours on my initial playthrough, without skipping anything, and a good bit of it was story and dialogue.
That said holy SHIT is the story and dialogue here [i]good[/i]. Almost every cutscene in the game gives you dialogue options, be it for flair, for potential humorous effect, or actually affecting the way other characters treat you in the long run.

To give an example (kinda spoilers but this happens literally in the second area you visit)...
There's a receptionist lady in one of the early levels that you can befriend depending on what you say, and she ends up not just helping you at the end of that stage, but also appears later on and can be talked to again, after she got fired from the hotel you slashed up and got a different receptionist job.
But if you antagonize her on your way in, she'll call the cops on you as you're on your way out, and your organization ends up taking her out as she's an unwanted witness. [i]Then the later area just gets a different receptionist instead.[/i]

I know a lot of games love to brag about [i]"""your choices matter trust us they actually do for real this time"""[/i], but this game's length genuinely helped a lot in actually making that semi-feasible to do. There's unique secrets to be found depending on how you act and what you choose to do throughout the story, including [i](something super secret you can get at the very end that i won't spoil but it has to do with how your psychiatrist sessions go)[/i].

...The story DOES unfortunately end on a cliffhanger which left me desperately wanting more though, but apparently there's going to be a DLC (?) or something like that coming later to give it closure. Free for owners of the game so, sure, alright. It's [i]definitely[/i] not an Asura's Wrath moment where they just make you pay extra to see the ending, and I appreciate that.



So yeah, you have a pretty short game, with a REALLY solid gameplay loop, and a really cool story that gets contextualized into the gameplay too (as every failed attempt of an area is just the protagonist "planning out his route" through and realizing that's not the way he should do things).

The visuals are REALLY good too; pixel art, yeah, which you've seen in a trillion indie games by this point, and the sprites aren't particularly big, but all the backgrounds and actual areas you walk through are RIDICULOUSLY detailed and atmospheric. From jumping through rainy rooftops at night, to climbing through a hotel while taking out an entire mafia's worth of goons, to the lit corridors of an abandoned slaughterhouse repurposed for... other things.
Almost all the areas stand out from each other from their theming and visuals, and the [b]synthwave soundtrack[/b] also really helps set the mood.

Mind you, I didn't walk out of the 100%ed game actively REMEMBERING many songs, there's not a lot of melodies that I could really say had that... [i]oomph[/I]? that makes game songs stick with me, but trust me, all the songs work really well in setting the dystopic-ass mood this game was going for. They work REALLY well in gameplay, it's just not something I would be particularly inclined to listen to outside of it.


Anyway, all that said. It's a good game, get it. It's short but it's worth the asking price.
MAAAYBE get it on sale if you're not convinced by the short length and potential lack of content (if you don't like finding hidden collectibles and secrets on replays of the story, or the speedrun mode), but either way it's worth a play.
Idunno if it's worth the [b]100%[/b] for everyone, getting that perfect speedrun in was a pain in the rear end, but it's worth AT LEAST a play.

139645452.review:
A beautiful action-platformer that's a [i]puzzle[/i] game of sorts -- in the very same way [i]Hotline Miami[/i] is -- in that it's all about you finding the best way to kill a level full of guys without getting one-shot yourself.  You're a crazy bathrobe samurai living in a cruddy apartment and you have a dependency for "chronos," a die-and-rewind drug that has permanently screwed up your sense of time.  You gotta have it; if you don't, time will freeze for you and you'll be stuck in a single, subjective moment forever.  

The feels, the kills:  Cool story interludes in a 32-bit futuristic city after a devastating war.  Psychiatrist is your handler and dope-giver.  Blood flash-sprays everywhere when you kill.  Cartoon goofball humor is mixed in with the serious bits -- anime-like in that regard.  Slow down time to surgically slash and roll past gunfire; fight a few tough bosses who are chemically or genetically modified; choose your dialogue or literally skip it with an imprecation or [i]brusque grunt[/i]; reflect bullets back at gunmen with well-timed swings.  

I really can't find anything to dislike about this super-fun game, other than that the story is not complete -- but the devs are working on free DLC to shore that up.  I feel like, for now, full-price is pretty steep if you're not figuring on getting gold in the Time Attack mode after you beat the brief and unfinished -- but very action-packed -- main campaign.  I might actually go back and get that gold, though . . . In the Devolver "Die by the Sword" bundle, it's a no-brainer.

139577638.review:
[h1] It's Like a Gory Version of Celeste [/h1]
This game RIPS so hard and really embodies the idea of a "combat puzzle" game. Most rooms require you to evaluate the situation and find the correct plan of action, and then execute that plan of action with decent window in-between each action. Choosing which enemy to kill first, which barrels to shoot, whether or not you should stealth a section, the game has plenty of variety in approaching situations and its amazing. Some of the situations do offer quite a bit of challenge, especially the boss fights.

That's just the gameplay though, the small segments in-between each killing floor really flesh this game out even further. The dialogue options you are given when speaking with the "therapist", the small talk you can make with the receptionist, it's not necessary at all but the fact that it's there elevates the series tremendously. The story is also fantastic, with you questioning "What the fuck is going on?" quite often. I got very invested in the story and I eagerly await the DLC. 

The 2D art style is also fantastic. The blood and gore in the scenes look great. My only detractor from the game would be that the stealth sections are kind of a drag if you choose that route. Dying requires you to keep doing them over again and waiting, but you do always have the option of going weapons loud. It's just you'll have to deal with the potential story consequences later.

[b] I would HEAVILY recommend that everyone pick-up this indie classic! [/b] Great story, great gameplay, and fantastic execution.

Katana ZERO is one of the best indie games ever made. A great story that presents us with Zero, a war veteran that has been hired to eliminate a dangerous drug to be available on the market. The story goes from watching memories, to killing everyone that comes to your path. Great bosses, also a secret one, and a overall, great campaign. Justin Stander is still working on the DLC, and it appears it will promise what was missing on the main game. However, the main game, music, design and replayability is incredible. Completing the game at 100% is not a so difficult task, however, as every 100% completion, it does take time. To me it took only 13 hours in total to finish at 100%, but it should normally take 10 and a half hours to be completed at 100%. The game is presented in a camera perspective, and dying means rewinding the "video", which is a great concept.

My final words:

"One of the most enjoyable assassin experiences, with a fast movement and a great learning curve for the most advanced gamers"

TL DR: Amazing game 10/10. Music is phenomenal, story is great, game play is satisfying and fluid. 15 euros is a fair price and I just recommend you play.

This masterpiece easily one of my favorite indie games of all time. Everything about it is amazing. The only issue is that it doesn't go on forever. The combat is really satisfying and getting the achievements for this game was fun as well. 

The game is structured around that fact that you die in one shot. The enemies however die in one shot too. What that means is that you have to weave around bullets and dodge incoming attacks with just your sword. The rolling, time slowing down and throwing mechanics work very well. On normal mode the game can be played reactively with you just parrying and dodging everything that comes at you. On hard mode however, you are forced to learn the layout of the level and find a strategy which will get you through as there are simply too many enemies.

The story is also amazing as there are many dialogue and in-game choices a player can make to affect dialogue and the endings. 

I cant write a lot about it because its just too good. Buy it right now. You wont regret it!

138399752.review:
Buenas! en el remoto caso de que estés viendo las reseñas para saber si comprar o no este juego hay algo muy importante que debes preguntarte primero:

[h1] TE GUSTA HOTLINE MIAMI? [/h1]
Si la respuesta es SI: Compralo. Es así de fácil. Este juego es muuuuuuy parecido tanto en la jugabilidad, la violencia, la velocidad, las escenas raras y enigmáticas, todo.

Ahora bien, si la respuesta es NO: pues.... no tienes mucho que hacer aquí. Mejor ve a jugar algo mas tranquilo como el Minecraft o que se yo. Acá estamos los loquitos que queremos ver SANGRE, REFLEJAR BALAS, SENTIR LA EMOCIÓN DE LA BATALLA, SEKIIIIIIROOOOOOO *cough cough* y todo eso.

[h1] PERO NO TENGO NI IDEA DE QUE ES HOTLINE MIAMI [/h1]
Bueno, esta es la 3ra opción en este caso, me va a gustar o no el juego?
Primero que nada, este juego va de matar, es tan simple como eso. Empezas el nivel tu pj se pone los auriculares como para hacer cardio y empieza a mandar sablaso limpio a todo lo que se mueve (Ah por cierto, no podes usar armas de fuego AY)
La GRACIA está en que si te pegan un tiro o te revientan la cabeza te morís de una (oh sorpresa!) y no tenes barra de vida.

Había una época que eran muy populares estos juegos y esa onda puede salir muy mal como muy bien por suerte Katana Zero tiene una estructura que lo hace ideal y queda espectacular.

Particularmente no soy fan de este tipo de juegos ya que ejercen muchísimo estrés en el jugador y si no estas acostumbrado a ello puede hacerte sentir mal, enojarte, ponerte triste, que se yo cosas asi.
La cuestión es que KZ lo hizo en pequeñas medidas manejables, además cuando empieza lo hace despacio como llevándote de la mano, como cuando tu viejo te enseña a andar en bici...

[h1] COMO QUE ANDAR EN BICI? QUE FLASHEAS FLACO? [/h1]
Bueno ya, la cosa es así el juego empieza suave y tierno como acariciándote la entrepierna, pero antes de que te des cuenta te va a hacer su perra y te va a dar duro contra el muro como puerta que no cierra, así que prepárate para eso.

Hay mucha variedad de enemigos, esa es una parte muy buena que lograron en el juego ya que tenes que adaptarte a cada uno (incluso al terminar la historia destrabas un modo donde agregan un par de personajes extras). Tenemos desde los típicos mafiosos a mano limpia hasta agentes de policías tácticos y cosas por el estilo.
Quizás, no sean tantos tipos técnicamente, digamos unos 5 o 6 como mucho pero la gracia es que el mapa también es variado y acompaña perfectamente, entonces no es lo mismo "Tipito con escopeta en espacio abierto" que "Tipito con escopeta detras de tipito con escudo"

Ahí está el truco que lo hace adictivo! cada situación tiene una fina estructura que tenes que recorrer casi a la perfección para que no te maten, aún así varias veces te van a matar pero no solo resucitas super rápido sino que encima con cada muerte aprendes algo, lo aplicas, ves que funciona y WALÁ MAGIA!

Una vez contemplas como hiciste el ejercicio mental de la mejor ruta el juego te recompensa mostrándote como pasaste el nivel, es un muy buen detalle y además te hace sentir bien y preparado para el siguiente nivel.

[h1] AUN NO ENTIENDO DE QUE VA, DEBE SER RE ABURRIDO SIEMPRE MATAR [/h1]
Esta es la parte donde entra la historia, lo bueno es que esta sección no va a ser larga ya que te estaría tirando terribles spoilers.

Solo te voy a decir que tu pj no recuerda un pomo de lo que fue o lo que hizo antes y bueno queda perfecto ya que el jugador tampoco sabe nada entonces mientras vas matando gente y contemplando la vida empezás a ver personas que te dicen cosas como "NULO" o te tiran nombres de drogas raras y bueno, vos ahí con tu inteligencia GAMER™ vas armando todo (yo igual no entendí todo pero hay cosas interesantes en la historia)

[h1] ENTONCES DEBERÍA PROBARLO... HAY ALGO MAS QUE NO ME ESTES CONTANDO? [/h1]
La música! LA MÚSICA WACHO!!! Dios está buena!!!! está mas buena que tu vieja!!! con eso te digo todo.
Ya está no te digo mas, compralo y jugalo no te vas a arrepentir. Agarralo antes de que el precio se dispare a las nubes!

RESUMIENDO: Juego frenético 2D con sistema de combate super rápido donde vas y matas a todo lo que se cruce con música super copada ideal para acompañarla
Si tuviera que darle un score le daría un excelente 8.5 solamente por ser relativamente corto, tener un final algo inconcluso y porque [u]FU.CK THE SPEEDRUN GOLD MEDAL.[/u]

138257975.review: Very stylish, even cinematic. The story is great and has a lot of well-built suspense and unexpected plot twists. Skill-wise the game is not easy, but also quite forgiving. You can often solve the room in different ways, and while you need to be quick and use your abilities, you also need to think a bit and plan. If you fail, the retries are quick and each segment is not too long, so many retries don't feel tedious. The game feels very well-made, with a lot of details. The only downside is that it's very linear, there is zero exploration and although dialogue options influence interactions and the plot a bit, you are forced to choose them quickly, so it still feels like you're locked on the rails. Overall an awesome game that leaves a very strong memorable impression!

138230376.review:
¡Me encontré con un auténtico regalo de los dioses! No tenía grandes expectativas al comenzar Katana Zero, pero resultó ser un juego impresionante. Con una estética ochentera y un exquisito pixel art, este título respaldado por Devolver Digital me cautivó por completo.

La historia gira en torno a un asesino samurái amnésico que utiliza drogas experimentales para predecir los movimientos en combate. Cada sección del juego se presenta como un plan que el personaje elabora mentalmente para enfrentarse a una serie de enemigos. Esto implica repetir la misma sección varias veces, aprendiendo los patrones de ataque de cada enemigo y descubriendo las mejores estrategias para derrotarlos.

La relación con títulos como Hotline Miami es evidente, tanto en términos de estética como en la premisa de repetir hasta encontrar la clave del éxito. La historia también guarda sorpresas y giros interesantes, que aunque puedas prever, no dejan de ser disfrutables.

La jugabilidad combina elementos de acción frenética y plataformas. Cada error nos obliga a reiniciar la secuencia desde el principio, lo que añade un nivel de desafío. Afortunadamente, tenemos libertad para abordar los combates, eligiendo qué enemigos enfrentar y cómo utilizar nuestras habilidades, que incluyen espadas, saltos, lanzamiento de objetos y la capacidad de ralentizar el tiempo.

El control del juego es exquisito, permitiéndonos incluso dirigir nuestros ataques en pleno vuelo. Además, el trabajo de pixel art en Katana Zero es impresionante, transmitiendo detalles sorprendentes a través de simples píxeles. Las animaciones son una delicia y la música contribuye a sumergirnos en la experiencia.

Increíble jugar en la steam deck, que funciona perfectamente y muestra el pulido y el nivel de detalle del juego. Katana Zero es un título que va más allá de su jugabilidad y su historia interesante, destacando también por su apartado visual y sonoro. Devolver Digital ha vuelto a demostrar su capacidad para publicar juegos de alta calidad. Indie imprescindible.

138129343.review:
Katana Zero proves that you can have style [i]and[/i] substance. You play as a samurai cosplayer with the abilities of precognition and slowing down time. Other mechanics include dodge rolls and wall jumps that give you i-frames, and the ability to reflect projectiles with your sword. The visuals are incredible, the soundtrack is a banger, and the story is interesting as well—although it's mostly linear and incomplete at the time I write this.

Note that this game was developed by one person; all the praise this game gets is more than well-deserved. They're also working on a free DLC that expands on the story, so make sure to follow the game if you decide to buy it.

If I had to rate:
- gameplay: 10/10
- soundtrack: 10/10
- visuals: 10/10
- story: 9/10

137904255.review:
Although I have plenty to criticize and I am flagging the review as "not recommended", I am actually *cautiously recommending* the game overall because the gameplay and the art alone are worth it. But this review is much more critical than your usual recommended review - hence the thumbs down (Steam should really add "neutral" reviews).

PROS:

- A platformer that borrows a lot from Hotline Miami gameplay and difficulty.
- Beautiful art-style with excellent animations and overall high production values. 
- Some very creative level design. 
- Good music with one track being particularly beautiful.

CONS:

- Personally, I couldn't care less about the story and dialogues. Found it cringe-worthy and try-hard. Various "edgy" bits didn't help either. Also why would I care about deaths of others after I slaughter countless people while a cool music is playing and everything about it feels cool? Tone-deaf. Didn't work for me at all. I have also become really allergic to "cute" and "sensitive" bits in otherwise "brutal" and "serious" stories. Pet a cat and other really pandering shit like that (not gonna spoil the story). I hope this cheap trend will die soon.

- I fucking hated the acceleration and inertia on the character movement - very frustrating when precision movement was required - especially if you prefer gamepad sticks instead of d-pad.

- Many pointless and illogical "choices" in the dialogues and in several actions/interactions - felt really unnecessary at many occasions. One level also required you to go through a dialogue repeatedly until you succeeded in selecting the right order of choices otherwise you fail. It was a simple trial and error. Boring, tedious and empty. Hated that.

- Randomized enemy positions and movement after each level restart lead to the player waiting/idle times. It's such a momentum killer. A way to get you off your adrenaline high. I consider this to be a design flaw in a game like this and yes I hated it in Hotline Miami too.

- A level editor with Steam workshop support would be nice (again a comparison with Hotline Miami).

137813469.review:
Good, but not great. Katana Zero is a very fun, fast-paced, brutal, stylish action platformer, BUT it could've been better imo. I was very excited to play it and despite how much I enjoyed it, I feel it was held back somewhat by its heavy emphasis on narrative and its adherence to Hotline Miami design tropes. This game wants to be Hotline Miami so bad. Ultraviolent psychopath main character having trouble discerning reality from hallucination, retro 80s aesthetic, girl supporting character that brings the good out of you, synthwave soundtrack, evil Russian guy, switch to playing an antagonist character, one hit death, forcing the player to walk back through the level after massacring everyone, sending the player back to their apartment after every hit. It's all there and more. There's even a part where our protagonist is asked if he likes violence. The issue I have is that it doesn't do it as well as Hotline Miami. 

Hotline Miami is a tight consistent experience. Katana Zero is sold as a fast paced action game yet has a handful of stealth sections that just slow the game down to a tedious crawl and just lead to a loud bloodshed anyway making me wonder what the point of it was. Mark of the Ninja, this is not. The soundtrack fits the tone nicely and is well-composed, but is mostly forgettable. A lot of the same beats you here in most synthwave is featured here. I feel like this genre is getting a bit too samey. I've listened to it fully outside of the game as well and few tracks stood out like equivalent synthwave offerings in games like Brigador, Furi, and obviously Hotline Miami. The game is extremely short, like 4 hours tops and that's taking my time, which would be fine if it was complete, but this game has no ending. It ends on a cliffhanger with a "To be continued..." message right as it hits its peak. This is a terrible approach as there's no guarantee any game would be enough of a success to even afford a follow-up. Hopefully, a conclusion is added here or in a sequel since the game is quite popular. That said, making your ending DLC would be awful. No one should have to pay extra for an epilogue. 

I found the story compelling enough, but nothing that left me pondering my actions like Hotline Miami did. That game was transgressive and didn't hold back on its dark exploration of violence. It managed to accomplish character development for Jacket without a single line of dialogue spoken from him. This game feels more like treading old ground. What hurt my enjoyment of the story is just how often it interrupts gameplay. Most missions are finished in a few minutes even with dozens of death. Don't worry. This game isn't that difficult and before anyone says to play on hard, you can't until you beat it once on its default difficulty. The prison level was especially egregious about this length problem. Way too short and underwhelming with more forced shallow stealth gameplay that basically never reappears in the rest of the game. Once done, I get more long conversations with dialogue options that have little effect on the outcome of the story. It seems to be only worth doing for achievements. If the story segments only came after the mission's been completed, this wouldn't be so bad, but there are instances of dialogue appearing mid-mission and it just breaks up the flow too much.

The level design feels like a missed opportunity more often than not. When they're more expansive with multiple routes/floors, I feel encouraged to experiment and plan my attack. However, many levels feel on-rails, ironically with there literally being a minecart level that's on-rails, and it's these levels that make me feel like I have to do things one way since there aren't any other approaches. Again, compare this to Hotline Miami where almost every level is basically the entire floor layout full of connected rooms allowing for numerous approaches. The tutorial is straight up deceptive. There's a part where you have to use bullet time to get past a fan without getting chopped up. This made me think there would be more environmental hazards where you have to slow down time to get past, but no, this never appears at any other point in the game. You could probably beat the entire game without bullet time. I didn't use it most of the time and just relied on trial and error to beat levels. Bosses are also fairly lackluster. With the exception of the final boss, they're extremely easy and predictable.

I sound negative, but I actually really liked the game and still recommend it. The core gameplay is the selling point for me. Rapidly cutting down foes and deflecting bullets is just too satisfying and addictive for me not to recommend it. I just thought it could be better. Nonetheless, the pixel art graphics are beautiful and this is one area where Hotline Miami just does not compete. I think if they borrowed less from Hotline Miami and added some meat to the game's lean offering, I'd be all for singing this game's praises. As is, it's another good Hotline Miami-like that's comfortable sitting in its shadow. I give it a 7/10.

137459350.review:
Just to get it out of the way: this game is 2D hotline miami. In gameplay, aesthetic, music and story, Katana Zero is just 2D hotline miami. If you have played hotline miami, you have already played this game. (None of this is a bad thing, mind)

Katana Zero is a brutally difficult action game where you die in one hit and have to clear out all enemies from a set of rooms in one go before moving on. It's the tried and true hotline formula with some added weeb shit for good measure. The gameplay does feel a bit strange at times where your character randomly won't attack when you needed him to or will get stuck on a wall when you desperately needed to fall, but reloading after death is instantaneous and nothing is more satisfying than finally nailing that perfect run and leaving without a scratch. Melee weapons are always more fun in games like this in my opinion, and getting up close and personal to hack some poor sap into mincemeat as the screen shakes and bassy synth music blares in your ears is amazingly immersive.

The story is so predictable that it's almost upsetting and it does nothing new with the 'cyberpunk dystopia' trope. Mentally troubled main character [spoiler] moonlights as an assassin and falls deeper into insanity while trying to redeem themselves with a new connection [/spoiler] with plenty of glitch effects and psychedelic dream sequences. As soon as a new character appears, you know exactly what's going to happen to them. As an aside though, when the credits rolled and 'to be continued' lit up my screen, I was so confused that I genuinely believed that the game was doing a bit and faking me out. At the current "end" the story barely feels like it has moved past the first act, ending on a massive cliffhanger. Nothing on the store page said anything about the story being incomplete or episodic, and having to now wait for the rest of the story in the form of (admittedly free) dlc is kind of a dick move on the devs' part. Just put something on the store page to let people know that the game's story isn't finished and it wouldn't be an issue.

All in all though even if the plot is nothing special, the gameplay alone makes this game worth dropping a couple bucks for 4 hours of gory fun.

136657747.review:
"People say that violent video games don't make violent people, but I'm five minutes in and I crave blood" -Alpharad, about a very different game. It still applies here.

Seriously though this game is an absolute adrenaline rush filled to the brim with hidden dialogue, secret options, and tons of replay value. As somebody with 25 hours in a 6 hour game, I can also verify that it's an absolute blast to achievement hunt and speedrun this game, as the mechanics allow you to be expressive in your playstyle to the absolute max. Think slowing down is lame and for weak little babies? You can deflect bullets in real time like a GOD. Hell there's even an option in the speedrun menu to turn off the mechanic entirely. 
Speaking of replay value, once you beat the game you get access to an entirely reworked hard mode with new enemies that make you have to adapt and change the way you think. Every time I go through this game, both in hard mode and in regular mode, I'm blown away by surprisingly detailed environments that you blow right through, actually funny dialogue options that you could completely miss, and even the ability to pet cats.

On my first play through I thought the story was a bit corny, with one or two unnecessary characters and an unsatisfying conclusion, but then I went back to explore options that I felt I might have missed and was proven very wrong. The game is full of blink-and-you-miss-it moments that can make your second time through feel like an entirely different story. If you were an absolute menace to everyone around you in your first play through, if you go back and e nice to them you'll be rewarded with a different side of these characters.

My only gripe with this game is that it is very clearly incomplete, and the devs actually made that abundantly clear in the credits where it's stated this is the "first act". Still, for the game coming out in 2019, it's disappointing that what we've gotten in hard mode and speedrunning mode aren't meant to expand on the genuinely interesting story and characters that we spend a criminally short time with. I'm just praying the DLC that they're making comes out soon enough to get the attention it deserves.
